title: BSD Conjecture: Millennium Prize Problem
content:
**The Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture**:

> The algebraic rank of an elliptic curve equals its analytic rank.

**Weak BSD**:
$$\text{rank}(E(\mathbb{Q})) = \text{ord}_{s=1} L(E, s)$$

**Strong BSD**: The leading coefficient at s = 1 is:
$$\frac{\Omega \cdot R \cdot |Ш| \cdot \prod c_p}{|E(\mathbb{Q})_{\text{tors}}|^2}$$

**Status: OPEN** — One of 7 Millennium Prize Problems ($1,000,000)

title: Elliptic Curves over ℚ
content:
**Elliptic Curve E/ℚ**:

Weierstrass form:
$$y^2 = x^3 + ax + b, \quad a, b \in \mathbb{Q}$$

**Discriminant**: Δ = −16(4a³ + 27b²) ≠ 0 (smoothness)

**j-invariant**: j = −1728(4a³)/Δ

**Key property**: E(ℚ) forms an abelian group under the chord-tangent law.

title: Mordell-Weil Theorem
content:
**Mordell-Weil Theorem (1922-28)**:

The group E(ℚ) of rational points is **finitely generated**:
$$E(\mathbb{Q}) \cong \mathbb{Z}^r \oplus T$$

where:
- r = **algebraic rank** (the key unknown!)
- T = finite **torsion subgroup**

**Mazur's Theorem (1977)**: T is one of exactly 15 groups.

**Computing r**: Major algorithmic challenge in arithmetic geometry.

title: L-Functions of Elliptic Curves
content:
**L-function L(E, s)**:

Euler product for Re(s) > 3/2:
$$L(E, s) = \prod_p L_p(E, s)^{-1}$$

**Local factors**:
- Good reduction: $L_p = 1 - a_p p^{-s} + p^{1-2s}$
- Bad reduction: depends on type

where $a_p = p + 1 - \#E(\mathbb{F}_p)$.

**Root number** w(E) ∈ {±1}: Determines parity of analytic rank.

**Key**: By modularity, L(E, s) has analytic continuation to all ℂ!

title: Modularity Theorem (Wiles)
content:
**Modularity Theorem (Wiles 1995, BCDT 2001)**:

Every elliptic curve E/ℚ is **modular**:
$$L(E, s) = L(f, s)$$

for a weight 2 modular form f.

**Consequences**:
1. L(E, s) has **analytic continuation** to all ℂ
2. **Functional equation**: Λ(E, s) = w · Λ(E, 2−s)

**Historical**: This theorem completed Fermat's Last Theorem!

title: Analytic Rank
content:
**Analytic Rank**:

$$r_{\text{an}}(E) = \text{ord}_{s=1} L(E, s)$$

The order of vanishing at the central point s = 1.

**Parity constraint** (from functional equation):
- w(E) = +1 ⟹ r_an is even
- w(E) = −1 ⟹ r_an is odd

**BSD predicts**: r_an = r_alg (algebraic rank).

This is the heart of the conjecture!

title: BSD Conjecture Statement
content:
**BSD CONJECTURE**:

**Weak form**: rank(E(ℚ)) = ord_{s=1} L(E, s)

**Strong form**: The leading coefficient is:
$$\lim_{s\to 1} \frac{L(E,s)}{(s-1)^r} = \frac{\Omega \cdot R \cdot |Ш| \cdot \prod c_p}{|E(\mathbb{Q})_{\text{tors}}|^2}$$

where:
- Ω = real period
- R = regulator (height pairing determinant)
- Ш = Shafarevich-Tate group (mysterious!)
- cₚ = Tamagawa numbers

title: Proven Cases of BSD
content:
**PROVEN CASES**:

**Rank 0** (Kolyvagin 1990):
$$L(E, 1) \neq 0 \Rightarrow \text{rank} = 0, Ш \text{ finite}$$

**Rank 1** (Gross-Zagier 1986 + Kolyvagin):
$$L(E, 1) = 0, L'(E, 1) \neq 0 \Rightarrow \text{rank} = 1, Ш \text{ finite}$$

**CM curves** (Coates-Wiles 1977):
For complex multiplication curves with L(E, 1) ≠ 0.

**Open**: Rank ≥ 2 cases completely unknown!

title: Gross-Zagier Formula
content:
**Gross-Zagier Formula (1986)**:

$$L'(E, 1) = c \cdot \hat{h}(P_K)$$

where:
- P_K = Heegner point from CM theory
- ĥ = Néron-Tate height
- c = explicit constant

**Significance**:
- Bridges L-functions (analysis) and rational points (algebra)
- If L'(E, 1) ≠ 0, the Heegner point is non-torsion
- Combined with Kolyvagin ⟹ rank = 1

title: Computational Evidence
content:
**Computational Verification**:

- BSD verified for **millions** of elliptic curves
- All curves with conductor N ≤ 500,000 checked
- **No counterexamples ever found!**
- Leading coefficient matches to high precision

**Congruent Numbers**:

n is congruent (area of rational right triangle) iff:
$$\text{rank}(E_n) > 0 \Leftrightarrow L(E_n, 1) = 0$$

where E_n: y² = x³ − n²x.

BSD connects geometry to L-values!

title: Why BSD is Hard
content:
**Obstacles to Proving BSD**:

1. **Higher rank**: Kolyvagin's methods only work for rank ≤ 1. No way to construct enough independent points for rank ≥ 2.

2. **Sha is mysterious**: Cannot compute |Ш| in general. Examples with |Ш| > 10⁸ exist!

3. **Finding points**: Even if rank ≥ 2, finding explicit generators is computationally hard.

4. **Average rank** (Bhargava-Shankar): ≤ 1, so BSD "usually" true, but proving it universally remains elusive.

title: Problem Status: OPEN
content:
**BSD Conjecture: Still OPEN since 1965**

**Proven cases**:
- Rank 0: L(E,1) ≠ 0 ⟹ rank = 0 ✓ (Kolyvagin)
- Rank 1: L(E,1) = 0, L'(E,1) ≠ 0 ⟹ rank = 1 ✓ (GZ + K)
- CM curves with L(E,1) ≠ 0 ✓ (Coates-Wiles)
- Parity conjecture ✓ (Dokchitsers)

**OPEN for rank ≥ 2**!

**Significance**:
- Central to modern number theory
- Connects arithmetic and analysis
- Applications to cryptography

**Prize**: $1,000,000 Millennium Prize
